body:
Yes. The requirement is to prevent any new actions from being created (or updated), and prevent any execution of already existing Swift 2 actions -- the developer should be warned that the runtime is deprecated.

I'm rebuilding now to remove conflicts.
Merged as 840c12f6dcb8993856b4aa410f364f08577975ce

This is going to be a great feature, looking forward to trying it out. 

Two things I noticed.... 
- Does the API endpoint need both a base path and api path? Is it possible to just have my API GW URLs at /action? 
- It is possible to have wildcard routes in the URLs? I'm thinking how to handle /app/users/1 and /app/users/2.
- It would be nice if the CLI helped you define multiple HTTP methods without requiring each as a separate command. 

```
wsk api create /store/pets  * my_action 
```

Also, I find the CLI output data a bit difficult to quickly scan. If I want to see the paths and associated actions from the CLI I have to read all the way to end of each URL field. The URL field has a lot of extra information that I have to parse to understand this. Could we add a 'path' field? I would like to see "path, verb, action, URL" in the output table.

@jthomas - Thanks for the comments and suggestions! 
- Currently, when creating an API endpoint mapping, the basepath argument is optional and will default to '/'; however, a relative path is required.  If I understand your example correctly, a single argument of `/action` would be the equivalent of a basepath of `/`, an api path of `/action` mapping to an action called `action`.  Fully qualified action names would result in api paths like `/whisk.system/utils/echo`.  Is my understanding correct?
- Re wildcard routes.  Maybe what you are asking for is how to create an api path that takes a path parameter?  At the moment that is not supported by the API GW; but we are aware of the need for this feature.
- Not currently.  At the moment, there's no way for an action to discern which HTTP method was used to invoke the action.  We have some thoughts on how to surface this information to the action; at that time, I think your suggestion would be a nice enhancement.
- Regarding the `wsk api list` output.  Would you like to see this additional path include both the base path and the api path, or just the api path?
PG1 861 - API GW CLI tests passed

Last Travis failure due to unrelated test case

```
system.basic.WskBasicTests > Wsk Action CLI should create and invoke a blocking action resulting in an error response object FAILED
    org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: "error: Unable to invoke action 'errorResponseObject': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
    " did not include substring that matched regex "error": "name '!' contains illegal characters \(code \d+\)"
```
PG2 599 - passed

- Thanks for explaining the background to the base and api paths. 
  
  It seems like the base and api path stuff is an implementation detail. I think it would improve the developer experience if you just let the developer provide a single URL path and have the tooling handle splitting it into base and api paths. 
  
  It looks like the tool expects to support this format already.
  I would remove the other styles (separate base and api paths) to reduce confusion.

```
wsk api create /store/pets                    delete deletePet
```
- Regarding HTTP methods. Can someone define more than one HTTP method for a URL (even though the action can't tell the method)?
- Regarding `wsk api list` I'd suggest showing the full path, combining the base and api path as per my recommendation above.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/f0ef11d1a42b0e2c73b7a9a1652a2a4e9fc6ffc7.
closing for #1533.
Merged as ca15c68d348a2a02cf9da54475e96b43d48a3dac
@ioana-blue up to you to close #992, #995 and #1253.
@rabbah, rebase complete.

- I think the challenge is to determine how much API-centric details to surface while configuring the action APIs.
  
  Due the the many possible API GW configuration properties, The CLI will probably not be able to provide args and options to fully configure every API option - in these cases, the API configuration can be exported (via the wsk CLI) in OpenAPI (i.e. Swagger) format, edited and then re-imported (via the wsk CLI).  The OpenAPI file will have basepath and path fields; so some understanding of this decomposition may be needed.
  
  Additionally, some folks may want more granular control of those values, so the CLI exposes them.  One possible way to support API-centric and OpenWhisk-centric developers is for the `wsk api create` command to accept a single argument in the form `/ACTION` - in addition to the allowing explicit basepath, api path and action arguments.  Would need to think a bit on how this would trickle out to the other commands.
- Right now, separate CLI commands must be used to assign separate HTTP methods to the same action.
- Re `wsk api list` suggestion.  I've opened issue #1534.
Merged

Thanks for the feedback @jthomas 
- splitting into `basePath` and `path` 
  About the UX for getting started, the user can provide a single string like `/cats/dogs/rain` but to have a solution that we can configure the apigateway service and be able to generate a swagger file/spec. we have to split it into a `basePath` and `path` these two fields are entity required, we can only assume how to split `/cats/dogs/rain`  currently we are splitting into `/` and `/cats/dogs/rain` this is if the user doesn't go explicit, thinking that would be the more conservative way. 
  So if user creates a `get` on `/cats/dogs/rain` and we decide to split into `basePath=/cats/dogs` and `path=/rain`. 
  If the user creates another api operation `post` with `/cats/dogs/rain/monkeys` it will create a second swagger spec and API definition with `basePath=/cats/dogs/rain` and `path=/monkeys`
  It might be an odd situation, but it might be OK since they always have the option to be explicit.
  With using `/` then it will create a single API swagger and every api operation command were are not explicit will be under this API swagger.
  The other way around every top parent path will create a new API swagger as long the first portion is the same.
  I think is something to think about what would be the best default.
- Using `*` for method as an override
  I think is a cool idea very nice shortcut, take into account that all verbs (options, head, get, put, post, delete, etc..) supported will be created, but I think for getting started it might be a convenience and also demo wise a good thing, before starting to talk the other more advance customizations and control like the swagger and being explicit.

@jthomas @mdeuser scratch my assumption 
~~So if user creates a get on /cats/dogs/rain and we decide to split into basePath=/cats/dogs and path=/rain.~~

basPath can't have subpaths, so allowing the short version to specify a Path I think is a good idea like
`wsk api create /store/nyc/pets get petaction`
It will be parsed basePath=`/store` and path=`/nyc/pets`
@rabbah LGTM, squash and merge?
replaced by #1532
LGTM.  Minor comment on one of the comment lines.
@csantanapr @mdeuser @jthomas wouldn't the current approach of making the base path an optional argument satisfy james requirement (which i agree is a very valid one) ?

the one concern i have with this approach is that it might come across as an arbitrary decision if we establish such a split convention.

eg. what if it want to have `/` as the base path for `/store/pets` ?

Proposal to finish off this issue based on above comments: there are three desired behaviors. I'm taking it as a constraint not to disrupt the (v1) API too much hence PUT will continue to mean create or update. As such, we have:
1. `PUT`: create entity iff doesn't exist else error
2. `PUT + ?XXX=true`: update entity if it exists, create it otherwise
3. `PUT + ?YYY=true`: update entity iff it exists, error otherwise

We currently use `XXX == overwrite` and support only `1-2` and not `3`.
- The HTTP response code for `2` should change from 200 to 201 when entity is created instead of updated.

So as not to break uses of `overwrite` via direct HTTP calls but admit the additional use (`3`), I propose to repurpose `overwrite` for `3` and add `force` for `2`. The CLI correspondingly would allow:
- `wsk action create` (same as `1`)
- `wsk action update` (same as `3` where now it means `2`)
- `wsk action create --force (same as`2`)
- `wsk action update --force (same as`2`)

The CLI would also alias `--force` to `-f` for convenience.

This satisfies @csantanapr (done in the backend) and @mdeuser (don't create on update by default) and preserve convenience for deployment scripts (choice of `-f` on `create` or `update`).

Soliciting thumbs up or down to adopt or reject, comments to refine.
Closing as duplicate of #239.
I've slowly started consolidating controller/API messages in the `Messages` https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/http/ErrorResponse.scala#L40.
One way to do this: create an echo action and sequence it with your existing actions.

For node, actions can export a `main` already and do not need to declare a global main.
We've also changed the action.invoke and trigger.fire to operate with promises.

For node, I propose we install into the base the `npm openwhisk` package and deprecate the `whisk` object. Context parameters will be made available as environment variables (in addition to `AUTH_KEY`, and` EDGE_HOST`, I propose adding `NAMESPACE` and `ACTION_NAME`).

The passing of context parameters via environment object is how we're currently injecting these values into other runtimes; one value per property name.

Proposed plan:

1. [x] install openwhisk npm package pinned of course
1. [x] add deprecation notice to whisk object in node actions (emit log message on use)
1. [x] add current "context" to Node and Java actions (makes all runtimes the same)
1. [x] prefix openwhisk "context" environment variables with `__OW_` in all runtimes
1. [x] add namespace, deadline and other useful metadata to action environment
1. [x] ~~add deprecation notice to use existing environment variables?~~
1. [x] migrate examples to use openwhisk package (see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/616#issuecomment-262132467)
1. [ ] migrate catalog actions as well (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/issues/157)

Eventually, remove whisk object and environment variables from node actions.
Thumbs up or down to accept proposal, comments to refine.

@mbehrendt - The CLI behavior would depend on the number of argument provided.  Explicit basepath specification requires 4 arguments.  Implied basepath specification needs 3 argument.
- `wsk api create /bp /p get action` (TODAY BEHAVIOR)
  
  basepath = /bp
  apipath = /p
- `wsk api create /p get action`   (TODAY BEHAVIOR)
  
  basepath = /
  apipath = /p
- `wsk api create /bp/p1/p2/p3 get action` (PROPOSED BEHAVIOR)
  
  basepath = /bp
  apipath = /p1/p2/p3

I give 👍 to the proposal

Just a refinement, I think this is more for the implementation details of the openwhisk npm module on how to pick up the env variables.

This environment variables could be use by the openwhisk npm module when not running in an action in real runtime, to configure the module.

I would like to see an environment variable that provides more info on the whisk edge point to include protocol, and port, this way I can use it for mocking and testing.
meaning I want to be able to run a server on 'http://localhost:3000' that mocks the whisk api for testing, and my actions to run them locally which whisk.invoke()  and it will send the request to 'http://localhost:3000' instead of 'https://openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net'. 
If we add 'http' to nginx edge for local dev it can be use to point to this also.

maybe making `__OW_EDGE_HOST` contain protocol and port info, or have that info in different variables.

@mbehrendt 

> eg. what if it want to have / as the base path for /store/pets ?

This can be still be supported by specifying the [BASE_PATH] value explicit form: 
`wsk api create [BASE_PATH] API_PATH API_VERB ACTION [flags]`

In your example would be:
`wsk create / /store/pets get action`
BASE_PATH=`/`
API_PATH=`/store/pets`

meaning that that example 1 from @mdeuser https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1535#issuecomment-261725124 today's behavior remains

I'm a bit lost on what your proposing, people can't go directly to a slack community and ask to be signup or signup directly. Slack only allows to send invitations, so most people what they use is [slackin](https://github.com/rauchg/slackin)  where it's a form, give some stats and basically is an automation of calling the Slack API to send the invite to the person.

I created a Slack team a while back https://openwsk.slack.com should we start using it? and use [slackin](https://github.com/rauchg/slackin) to handle the invites?

We can deploy it and hosted out of url: http://slack.openwhisk.org

slackin it's what we use for the Apache Cordova project http://slack.cordova.io

I think having a Slack Team for OpenWhisk, would be beneficial as it would allows to have multiple channels

We can even create a channel for bluemix, or any other operator that wants a channel.

The current one about #openwhisk on bluemix is in dwopen can still remain
http://slackindwo.mybluemix.net/
@rabbah thanks for the writeup, I agree with proposal

slackin requires deployment hence servers. I am suggesting a "serverless " solution. Have an action call the slack API to send invite to interested parties wanting to join the community.

I was not suggesting a new slack community since we already have one - that is orthogonal to this feature proposal.

EDGE_HOST already includes the port. We made a decision long back to only support https at the edge. Hence we striped protocol out. I suggested in the openwhisk-client-js repo a heuristic that satisfies the request you're making. I've also used it in the test attached to the pull request for this issue.

OK that's why I was kind of confuse, this website http://slackindwo.mybluemix.net/ do this today for our Slack community.

Are you talking about an implementation like a sample that is generic that people can use serverless instead of slackin to invite people to their Slack team?
For this we need to get to a point that ow can serve html thru the controller/edge or apigw

in my mind, there is too much implied behavior.

an alternative proposal: when there is not basepath parameter specified, its value is always `/` by default.

with that, we don't surprise developers with setting basepath to some implied value which might not be clear to the,. we just do exactly what they requested via the cli.

what are your thoughts on this?
when dropping log information -- how do we continue to provide enough information to developers for problem determination? i think we should err on the side of providing more than less information...

can we limit the size of each record getting logged instead of dropping the entire log entry irregardless of the size of what is being logged in a particular entry?

to @sjfink 's original issue description -- i think we should rather establish a policy of deleting old entries vs reducing the log details per entry.

When dropping log information? There was no suggestion to drop log information. The issue I referenced above is to trade off trigger activation records for ones where user explicitly logs trigger payloads if they want to persist them. 

The feature request in this issue is to record the invocation parameters in the activation record. Instead of doing that I suggested if one want to do that they can sequence an action to record activation parameters either by logging them or as the result of an echo action. 

In other words the system already provides a way for the user to record incoming parameters.

We're not talking about dropping logs. Triggers don't have logs. I some time ago allowed triggers to record their payload as their result in the activation record. One can do this logging explicitly by sequencing an action hence no information is lost.

Logs separately are subject to a system limit of 10MB currently.

as you said you can work around it with sequences, but i as a dev wouldn't want to do this all the time. would be much nicer if that information would just be persisted without me having to do anything.

wrt 'dropping' -- i referred to your stmt "where we might drop activation records for triggers altogether (and we're entertaining dropping the payload content for triggers already)."
one quick question -- how would this proposal support situations where the variable value changes while the action invocation is ongoing?
CLI path specification discussion has moved to #1535

@mbehrendt - What you described is the the current implementation behavior, with the added stipulation (per OpenAPI/Swagger spec) that the relative path begin with `/`.  I tend to agree that we should be careful how much implied configuration the tooling provides; API definitions should be carefully thought out to allow for longevity and future growth.

Let's clarify terminology. Logs are user generated. The activation record contains the user generated logs in addition to other properties.

So we're discussing whether the system should automatically log input parameters to all invocations. We can't store these in user generated logs because they would take away from the quota. If the user wants to log them it's simple enough to do from their code. If the code is not accessible to the user the alternative is a sequence - an openwhisk strength and it's quite convenient to create new sequences.

So on one hand we leverage the strengths of the system for the case where user wants to log parameters. On the other we pay the extra overhead of recording all parameters for all activations in the system. 

Without establishing a retention policy on the activation records, and without evidence that the common case is to want the parameters logged vs not, I posit the system already provides the desired functionality.

ah -- you're suggestion that developers should just do a `console.log(<parameters>` in their code if they want to have parameters logged? yeah, i think that would be fine, at least in the short-term.

besides that, i think there is a retention policy needed in any case.
Could we expose the namespace, while at it? I think it's required if an action wants to reliably dynamically invoke itself.
Yes. Namespace, action name and deadline all coming up.
@mbehrendt Which values do you have in mind?

Manually logging the parameters is a sensible solution in the short-term.
I still think the system recording the invocation parameters somewhere would be a "nice to have" feature. People often don't set up logging until after something goes wrong.

Having this feature would also ease having tools that automated analysis or replay of invocations. It's more difficult to implement these tools if the parameters are in user logs, as opposed to a structured API response field.

Discussing this with @rabbah, I'm going to implement the changes to support https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-js/issues/1 and https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-js/issues/14. 

I also had an idea to allow the module constructor to automatically pick up configuration from environment parameters without manual configuration.

```
var ow = openwhisk()
// ... without explicit params, look for __OW__* variables in the environment.
```

The user can still provide this configuration explicitly to override the defaults or work outside the OpenWhisk platform. 

It will simplify the user experience and reduce the possibility developers make mistakes passing in the configuration, leading to random bugs.

I think we should think of the UX as a developer focusing in a specific language, and then later see what's common across.
For example me a NodeJS fanboy :-) , I have the same complaint that forcing me to create a function and name it `main` is not natural, also not natural not allowing me to export my action thru as the module using `module.exports`

We should start with good and simple way, to allow to export the module as the action function like:
```
//es6
module.exports = (params)=> params;
//es5
module.exports = function (params) {return params};
```
I like that zip nodejs actions today use `module.exports` but I don't like this `module.exports.main`
Why the extra `main` ? Not need it I think. I prefer the anonymous (just a preference :-)) 
I know that lambda and other have this extra level like `modules.exports.handler`, I think having the extra handler is OK but not necessary as a base level to get started with simple actions.

For nodejs we can have customization with nice fall back defaults allowing for backwards compatibility.

Let's say we added a property to the action metadata call `Handler: string`
If Handler is defined (let's say `Handler: 'handler'`) then we assume user did this:
```
module.exports.handler = (params)=> params;
``` 
Then if Handler is not defined we can check for `main` to see if user did this (for backwards compatibility, or deprecated)
```
module.exports.main = (params)=> params;
```
Then if Handler not defined, and no function in `module.exports.main`, then we can check if the user exported the action as the module like
```
module.exports = (params)=> params;
```

One more benefit or having a metadata `Handler` also allows for folks getting in the serverless space to try out openwhisk re-using code where they are already exporting a [named function](https://darrenderidder.github.io/talks/ModulePatterns/#/7)
@markusthoemmes "it may be better to define a language-neutral attribute on actions" -- I'm imagining an attribute called "entrypoint" (or something) in the standard schema for all actions.
@jthomas yes, this was I had in mind 👍  for changes to the client js library constructor, use env ad default or override explicit

@sjfink this "entrypoint" is what I'm referring in my comment https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/47#issuecomment-261955764 as `Handler` we are same page on that, but would like it to see it as an optional thing, not required at least for nodejs.

@rabbah this might be orthogonal to this issue but wanted to comment.
I think having the option to export the action as the module simplifies things a bit IMHO
```
module.exports = function (params) {return params};
```
I left the details of my proposal in my comment in issue #47 https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/47#issuecomment-261955764
As it doesn't exclude to still have `exports.main` or `exports.handler`
@csantanapr I'm discussing only the schema for action records in our cloudant database -- just an implementation detail -- not anything user-visible.
Defer to 47 -  I don't see what It has to do with this issue.
Can we bump the OW module version to 2.3.0?
@csantanapr great, I've added all the changes now with 2.3.0

It would be nice to support both 
`module.exports =`
and 
`module.exports.handler =`
where handler is a user-defined value as this would make it easier to migrate functions over from Azure and Lambda.

Thanks for creating this to track the work @rabbah . Not knowing the _Deploy to Bluemix_ workflow I'm sharing my thoughts on this to get feedback and improve the idea collaboratively.

Goal:
* streamline the _time-to-value_ for developers trying openwhisk 
* let developers focus on the code first and later learn about wsk CLI & friends

Assumptions: 
* JS actions only for start
* The GitHub repo can be github.com or another GitHub Enterprise deployment
* The GitHub is accessible by the OpenWhisk deployment
* The Developer writing the action/function doesn't have to know about:
  * wsk cli
  * setting up wsk credentials 
  * any other wsk internals
* if developers want to include extra libraries / npm modules they need to upload them into the git repo so that all the code can be downloaded from Git in a simple archive format.
* developers would eventually use the `wsk ` CLI for more advanced use-cases

The workflow would be as follows:
* the developer clones an existing GitHub repo containing a `hello-world` function or some other simple action
* the `README` of the repo contains instruction for setting up
  * create a webhook to the new repository by either:
     * setting up the hook manually in the GitHub UI
     * adding an `access token` into a manifest
     * maybe include the button *Deploy To Openwhisk* as part of the `README`
* invoke the function via a REST API
* other examples may include more info for setting up event handlers with feeds and triggers

Implementation details:
* create an OpenWhisk function to download a Git Archive and update/create an action from it
* reuse the [manifests](https://github.com/openwhisk/wskdeploy/tree/master/tests/testcases/helloworld) from the [wskdeploy](https://github.com/openwhisk/wskdeploy) project
* when a manifest file is missing assume some defaults:
  * src of the function is `main.js`
  * action name = git org and git repo name. maybe `<git_org>/<git_repo>` or if `/` is an invalid character for the name use `_`: `<git_org>_<git_repo>`
  * namespace = a default namespace that maps to the GitHub deployment. I.e for github.com use `github.com` as namespace. This ensure there's no collision if GitHub is combined with GitHub enterprise for instance.
* use a preconfigured whisk user ( i.e. `wsk_deployer`) for creating/updating actions created in GitHub *OR*
* automatically configure a new user in openwhisk based on the GitHub ID / owner of the new repo . TBD how developers can link accounts later when creating their own accounts.

Hi @bseyb I started looking into the design on providing a way to filter changes for the cloudant trigger.

Looking at the spec of the [changes API](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/latest/api/database/changes.html)

It looks like a filter and docs_id is doable, a filter will be a filter function on a design document.

What I didn't find was `oldDoc` during my testing the changes feed only provide the id and `deleted=true` and the new revision marked as deleted.

I was not able to find a reference to `oldDoc` in the changes API params.
Could you share a bit more where you saw this reference?

I agree it's odd, we should look into it 
to see if we can support resolve() and reject() with no argument the proxy has the ability to detect this and handle it appropriately

I think it's a good safety measure to be explicit and have the extra step by default. 
Maybe have an option -force for those that want to it in one http call

Isn't it what "--disable" flag is already doing?

$ wsk rule delete --help
delete rule
Usage:
  wsk rule delete RULE_NAME [flags]

Flags:
      --disable   automatically disable rule before deleting it
